Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal - Quantifying the footprint of a dominant organism: Biogeochemical impacts of leaf cutter ants in a lowland tropical forest ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide information on the contribution of an ecologically important ant guild to the carbon cycle and will help improve predictions of future carbon dynamics in tropical forests. One of the most conspicuous features of a tropical forest is the abundance of leaf cutter ants. Despite their prominence, little is known about the overall contribution of leaf cutter ants to carbon and nutrient cycles in tropical ecosystems. These tropical and subtropical forested ecosystems cover 17% of the Earth's land mass and store approximately 40% of all carbon and are an important determinant of the global carbon cycle. Leaf cutters are the dominant herbivores in tropical forest ecosystems, bringing 10-50 % of all surrounding vegetation into the nest, fertilizing nest soils, and promoting the release of carbon dioxide and methane into the atmosphere. The network of leafcutter ant trails extend throughout the forest and workers walk single-file, carrying pieces of leaves into their nests, where special fungi break down the plant material and produce hyphae, on which the ants feed. Leaf cutter ant nests are massive in size and during nest construction and maintenance ants mix leaf particles into the soil and alter soil chemistry. Leaf cutter ant activities have the possibility of controlling aspects of ecosystem dynamics, though the degree of their influence has not been quantified.

The project will focus on the role of leafcutter ant nests as hotspots of carbon dioxide and methane emissions and the role of nests in altering soil chemistry and creating heterogeneity in carbon (C), nitrogen (N), and phosphorus (P) in the soil across the landscape. The work will be conducted at La Selva Biological Research Station, Costa Rica, which is an epicenter of tropical scientific research, hosting a large number of student groups, researchers from all over the world. The project will characterize C dynamics on leafcutter ant nests and differentiate the sources of carbon dioxide and methane emissions between the activities of ants, fungi, the nest microbial community, and roots and hyphae. The N, and P biogeochemistry of active leafcutter ant nests will be quantified as well as the soil legacy effects after nests are abandoned. The project uses a multi-faceted approach, including coupling continuous measurements of soil carbon dioxide emissions with discrete measures of methane efflux, stable C isotopes of carbon dioxide to determine sources, soil C and N pools and fluxes, estimates of root and fungal biomass, and microbial community and functional indices. Measurements will be performed on ant nests, paired non-nest sites, and along a sequence of nests abandoned at different times in the past to quantify how long the impact of altered biogeochemistry persists in areas occupied by nests. These biogeochemical fluxes will be incorporated into an ecosystem model to estimate C flux at local-to-regional scales. The project will strengthen international collaborations by working with researchers and students from the US, Costa Rica, and New Zealand. In addition to training a postdoctoral researcher and mentoring several REU students, project scientists will conduct an annual workshop to introduce students and researchers to cutting edge field instrumentation and analysis techniques and provide opportunities to use these new approaches at La Selva. La Selva Biological Research Station is an epicenter of tropical scientific research, hosting a large number of student groups, researchers from all over the world, and serving as a center for ecotourism, thus the proposed research will be widely disseminated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to determine the type and magnitude of the effects of leaf cutters ants (LCA) on soil ecosystem processes.  Leaf cutter ants are the dominant herbivore of the humid forests of the New World Tropics, where they are estimated to be responsible for 25% of all foliage consumption.  Leaf cutter ants remove pieces of leaves and flowers one piece at a time and carry them into massively large colonies compared to ant colonies of the temperature zone. The ants do not eat the leaves but instead feed the leaves to a fungus that they consume as food.  The large amount of leaves they remove and deposit belowground, about 1 to 2 tons of fresh leaves per year for a single colony, represents a significant concentration of ecosystem carbon and nutrients such as nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) into an area of ~ 20-80 m2.  Given this deposition of carbon and nutrients into these nests, we predicted there would be significant effects of nests on carbon and nutrient cycling processes.  The large amount of concentrated leaf material as it breaks down should release carbon as CO2 gas and as dissolved inorganic carbon as well as nutrients that would be available for plant roots to exploit. We asked:

1) What are the effects of nests on the amount of carbon deposited, stored, and released from soil and what are the contribution of the activities of ants, the fungi, the nest microbial community, and roots?

2) How are nitrogen and phosphorus cycled in LCA nests compared to control areas and what are the legacy effects of nests on these nutrients after nests are abandoned?

3) What are the influence of LCA nests on CO2 fluxes at the ecosystem scale?

Our study was conducted at the La Selva Biological Station in the Atlantic lowlands of Costa Rica. Using a randomized survey, we found nest densities were greatest in the regenerating open pasture (2.7 nests per hectare (2.5 acres) and lowest in secondary forest 1.6 nests per hectare, with old growth forest intermediate. The average nest surface area was 67 m2, while the number of vents was 32 with openings averaging 0.00021 m2, or around 0.007 m2 total area of vent openings per nest (vent:nest area ratio of about 1:10,000).  Nests covered just over 1 % of the land surface area in pasture and forests. Belowground production of hyphae and root calculated using averages of standing crop biomass and lifespans indicates that belowground productivity is greater in nests than the control areas. Hyphal production was 3-fold higher in the nests than control areas (723 and 227 g C m-2 yr-1, respectively). Root production was also much higher (5X) in nests than the control (1230 and 235 g C m?2 yr-1, respectively).

Inorganic phosphorus (PO4) and microbial P were both significantly higher in nest surface soils, possibly resulting in part from the continuous excavation activities in nests and the deposition of deeper P-rich soils on the surface.  Activity of enzymes that break down materials to release P was higher in nest soils, suggesting that P availability is highest in nest soils. Carbon degrading enzyme activity was greater in nests than in non-nest controls, but only in the sites with more nutrient rich soils.  Several nests were abandoned during the study period. We found that the structure of the surface soil created by the LCAs began to break down almost immediately. Abandoned nests became hotspots for soil invertebrates and new root and AM hyphal expansion. The primary visible legacy was the open characteristics of the soil. Soil nutrient and gas concentrations were intermediate between control and nest sites, converging towards the control sites.

We determined that LCA nests maintain lower soil CO2 (relative to control soils) levels because they fundamentally change soil structure and gas flow dynamics inside nest soils. The latter appears to be the result of more efficient soil gas diffusion due to LCA-reduced soil tortuosity (ability of gas to pass through soil). The differences between nests and controls are seasonal, more pronounced during the wet season, when precipitation blocks gas transport in control soils. Measurements of CO2 leaving from the soil surface and from vents indicated that more CO2 is released from nests than control areas because CO2 is leaving the vents at a rate 100000X faster than from the soil surface. Thus, LCA nests are hotspots for CO2 release, as might be expected given the large amount of organic matter breaking down in them, but their architecture prevents build up of CO2 in the soil. These values suggest that an average Atta cephalotes nest area emits around 0.2 to 0.6 t CO2 per nest and year, i.e., 15% to 60% more than an equivalent area of soil in a lowland tropical forest.
